Part 1 of 3Audrey wants to buy some specialty fabric to make her kindergardner Nihad a halloween costume. The fabric store tells her that the fabric costs \displaystyle{9.69}\ \frac{\text{dollars}}{{\text{yard}^{{2}}}}. Note about this unitNote: Typically, when a fabric store says "yard", they actually mean "square yards". In this problem, I have written it out in the correct format: \displaystyle\text{yards}^{{2}}
Audrey is sure she saw this advertised online for \displaystyle{0.60}\frac{\text{cents}}{{\text{inch}^{{2}}}}, and she wants to know if it is a better deal in the store or online. She will take a minute to convert the price from \displaystyle\frac{\text{dollars}}{{\text{yard}^{{2}}}} to \displaystyle\frac{\text{cents}}{{\text{inch}^{{2}}}} to see which is the better deal.
Audrey knows the following facts:
\displaystyle{1}\ \text{yard}={3}\ \text{feet}

Part 2 of 3 The correct expression is:
